ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the culture behind the Vietnamese language and was able to fix my subtle mistakes in my speaking

I learned the alphabet, multiple Vietnamese phrases, pronunciation, and a lot more about Vietnamese culture. Coming into this class, I could only speak Vietnamese, and I learned how to both read and write!

Strengthened my fluency in Vietnamese a lot. I placed myself into this class as a heritage speaker and Professor Quang offers packets for heritage speakers who didn't take L1 and L2 to do so they can catch up and work on their writing skills. There is plenty of practice to speak and I definitely became a lot more comfortable with my reading and speaking skills with this class.
Furthered my knowledge of Vietnamese language and culture.
I learnt how to speak, read, and write Vietnamese

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The class could be a little bit more organized when it comes to grading and uploading grades on Canvas.

One huge strength is the professor. I thought Thy Quang was an excellent teacher. He did his best to teach us Vietnamese, was extremely flexible with deadlines, and accommodating his students. He also gave us very interesting assignments. At times, the workload definitely felt very hard though, but since he is so flexible with deadlines, I did not see this as a huge issue.
Integrating more coursework into Canvas could be useful to help students better keep track of assignments and due dates.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Recommended for everyone who is L3 level or a heritage speaker! Thay Quang is very understanding and patient.

I would recommend this course to anyone who would want to continue their education in Vietnamese. I solidfied what I already knew and learned a lot while being more confident in carrying on conversations.

Yes! Prof was very understanding of all troubles, and I felt like this class simulated what education is meant to be: intellectually thoughtful but also low stress. The best way to describe this class is chaotic good. At times, it may feel a little messy in terms of structure, but I believe Prof Quang is doing his best to help students learn. All he wants is for your success, and as long as you make an effort to turn in your assignments , you will do fine and improve your Vietnamese.
I would definitely recommend this course to heritage speakers or whoever else is ready for L3. It was a great course!

Yes! Professor Quang is an amazing professor who is very understanding and since the class size is pretty small, everyone gets to know each other very well. The work isn't too hard and you'll learn about more than just the language in here which is amazing.

Yes. The course helps strengthen heritage Vietnamese speakers' grasp on the language, especially with writing. As a student without any background in Vietnamese, the course was more challenging than non-accelerated L3 language courses at Yale, but I nonetheless felt very accommodated and learned a lot.

Yes. If you are a Vietnamese person who has lost touch with your mother language, this is the class to take. I am feeling more confident about my VIetnamese and I know after finishing L4 next semester, I will be able to talk to relatives without embarrassing myself.
